summary:
I’m a licensed clinical social worker, Licensed in both NY and NJ, with a background in behavioral and mental health as well as in healthcare.
I provide individual therapy to clients going through various mental health concerns including depression and anxiety. I work with clients on implementing behavior modifications to improve their overall mental health.
I also have a background in healthcare and have worked in various healthcare settings serving different populations. 
I am SIFI certified and have mentored many graduate students. 
Aside from providing mental health counseling, I am specialized in renal social work working in various outpatient dialysis clinics. 
I provide private individual therapy to adults, children, and families for various mental health concerns including depression, anxiety, adjustment, and behavior modification. 
I am trained in CBT, STI, motivational interviewing, PMT and PCIT.

message.text: May is Mental Health Awareness month. Let’s bring some #mentalhealthawareness
You are human, stop being soo hard on yourself! It's ok NOT to be okay and reach out for support. #TakeAMentalHealthMoment #MentalHealthMonth

ingestedContentSummary.description: Rachel Salamon is a Licensed Clinical Social worker with a background in behavioral and mental health. Rachel graduated with her masters from Columbia University School of Social Work. She provides individual and group therapy to clients or all ages...
ingestedContentSummary.fullText: Rachel Salamon is a Licensed Clinical Social worker with a background in behavioral and mental health. Rachel graduated with her masters from Columbia University School of Social Work. She provides individual and group therapy to clients or all ages going through various mental health conditions including depression, anxiety, defiance, familial relationship struggles, and life stressors.
ingestedContentSummary.title: Rachel Salamon - Licensed Clinical Social Worker | Headway

message.text:
Great news! I am now not only licensed in NY but in New Jersey as well! Accepting most major insurances. 
https://lnkd.in/egcfXA2k

In my PCIT work I often meet with parents who want to know the best way to discipline their child. They report “nothing is working” “the behaviors are just escalating”. My response is usually “just start praising”. The more we give attention to negative behaviors, the more likely they will be to occur. Let’s give attention to the positive behaviors instead. 
I challenge parents to recognize that one positive moment, and make it a big deal. Sounds easy, but it’s often harder than we think!
This article is a great and quick read!

ingestedContentSummary.description: If you’re exhausted and running out of ideas to correct your child’s difficult behaviors, you’re not alone. As I’ve learned, disciplining children with ADHD often means trying a few key strategies with one great twist – there’s actually no punishment involved at all!
ingestedContentSummary.title: The Secret to Better Behavior? No Punishment at All

message.text: "Punishing a child with ADHD for difficult behaviors is ineffective and counterproductive."	Merriam R. Sarcia Saunders, LMFT	additu.de/disc
